misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different problem (average acceleration) instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t rather than solving the given task of reading 5 integers and summing only the even ones. As a result, none of the rubric requirements (reading 5 integers, looping over them, checking evenness, accumulating a sum) are addressed.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the assignment is to compute the average acceleration given v0, v1, and t, so they read three doubles, compute (v1 - v0) / t, and print that value.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user (e.g., using Scanner and either individual reads or a loop), iterate over them (typically with a loop), check each number with n % 2 == 0 to identify even numbers, accumulate the sum of only those even numbers, and finally print the sum in the required format.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of '5 integers'.
Inputs are read as three double values rather than five integers.
No loop is used to process multiple values; only three scalar reads occur.
No conditional check (like n % 2 == 0) appears anywhere in the code.
The program computes (v1 - v0) / t and prints 'The average acceleration is ...' instead of summing even numbers and printing 'Sum of even numbers: ...'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between this exercise and a different textbook-style problem about average acceleration, leading the student to implement the wrong algorithm entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and rewrite main to: (1) prompt for and read 5 integers, (2) use a loop to process each integer, (3) use an if (n % 2 == 0) check to detect even numbers, (4) accumulate their sum in a variable, and (5) print the final sum with the required message.
related_concepts: Using the modulus operator for even/odd checks
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (input prompt, variable names, formula, and output message) matches a standard acceleration example and does not address any part of the stated task about summing even numbers.

evidence.note: The code reads three doubles v0, v1, t, computes acceleration, and prints it, instead of reading 5 integers, checking for even numbers, and summing them.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misinterpretation of Assignment Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for calculating average acceleration instead of the required task: reading 5 integers and summing only the even ones. This results in fundamental errors across all required programming concepts (input handling, loop structure, conditional logic, and calculation).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this code satisfies the requirement, likely confusing the current assignment with a previous or different programming task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must be structured to specifically handle 5 separate integer inputs, use repetition (e.g., a loop) to process them, and employ conditional logic (i.e., the modulo operator) to filter and sum even numbers.
symptoms: Program prompts for and reads variables v0, v1, and t.
Program uses `double` types instead of `int`.
Program reads 3 inputs instead of 5.
Calculation performed is (v1 - v0) / t, not an accumulation of even inputs.
Required control flow structures (loops, conditionals) are entirely absent.
misconceptions.root_cause: Task confusion or submitting code intended for a different problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully reread the problem statement for Q1: Sum of Even Numbers. Write a new program from scratch following those specific requirements.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code provided solves an entirely different physics problem, demonstrating zero progress on the actual assignment.

evidence.note: The prompt corresponds to an acceleration problem, not the summing of 5 integers.
The code reads 3 double values instead of 5 integer values.
The calculation finds acceleration, completely omitting the logic for checking even numbers and accumulating their sum.

misconceptions.name: Solving the Wrong Problem
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted code that solves a completely different problem (calculating acceleration) instead of the assigned problem (sum of even numbers). This indicates a fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment or a copy-paste error.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving the acceleration problem, reading three doubles (v0, v1, t) and computing (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers, checking which ones are even (using n % 2 == 0), summing only the even numbers, and printing the result.
symptoms: Code reads three doubles instead of five integers
No loop structure present
No even/odd checking logic
No accumulator for sum
Output is acceleration calculation, not sum of even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code for an unrelated problem, possibly due to confusion about assignment requirements, copy-paste error, or working on wrong file.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. You need to: (1) read 5 integers in a loop, (2) check if each is even using n % 2 == 0, (3) add even numbers to a running sum, (4) print the final sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submitted code solves an entirely different problem (physics acceleration) with no overlap to the required problem (sum of even numbers).

evidence.note: The entire program solves an acceleration problem, not the required sum of even numbers problem. Prompts for v0, v1, t; reads doubles; calculates acceleration.

misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different problem (average acceleration) instead of required sum of even numbers
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even ones, so none of the required problem logic (reading 5 ints, loop, even check, accumulator) is present.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t and computes the average acceleration ( (v1 - v0) / t ).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, iterate over them (e.g., with a loop), check each number for evenness using n % 2 == 0, accumulate the sum of even numbers only, and print that sum.
symptoms: Prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers
Uses double variables v0, v1, t instead of 5 integer variables or a loop
Computes (v1 - v0) / t instead of summing even numbers
No loop, no modulus (%) operation, and no accumulator for even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different textbook or assignment exercises, leading to implementing the average acceleration example instead of the sum-of-evens problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and rewrite main so it: (1) prompts for 5 integers, (2) uses a loop to read each one, (3) uses n % 2 == 0 to detect even numbers, (4) keeps a running sum of the evens, and (5) prints the final sum in the required format.
related_concepts: Using modulus operator to test even numbers
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program matches a standard average-acceleration example and contains none of the constructs required for reading 5 integers or summing even numbers.

evidence.note: Code reads v0, v1, and t as doubles and computes average acceleration instead of reading 5 integers and summing even numbers; no loop, modulus, or accumulator for even values.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Problem Implementation

misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code intended for calculating average acceleration, possibly confusing it with the current assignment (Q1. Sum of Even Numbers).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The solution must be built around reading 5 integer values, not 3 double values for physics calculation.
symptoms: Code calculates acceleration.
Code reads 3 double inputs, not 5 integer inputs.
Output text mentions 'acceleration' instead of 'sum of even numbers'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misidentification of the required problem or submission of the wrong file.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment prompt for Q1 and implement the solution that reads five integers and finds the sum of the even ones.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student's code is verbatim the solution for an acceleration problem, which is entirely different from the problem described in the prompt.
